journal-title-group.journal-title: The Journal of Clinical Endocrinology and Metabolism

title-group.article-title: Glucose Homeostasis and Energy Balance in Children With Pseudohypoparathyroidism

article-meta.aff: 1Wake Forest University School of Medicine, Winston-Salem, North Carolina
2The George Washington University School of Medicine and Health Sciences, Washington, DC
3Department of Biostatistics, Vanderbilt University Medical Center, Nashville, Tennessee
4Department of Pediatrics, Division of Pediatric Endocrinology, Vanderbilt University Medical Center, Nashville, Tennessee

author-notes.corresp: Correspondence and Reprint Requests: Ashley H. Shoemaker, MD, Department of Pediatrics, Division of Pediatric Endocrinology, Vanderbilt University Medical Center, 1500 21st Avenue South Street, Suite 1514, Nashville, Tennessee 37212. E-mail: ashley.h.shoemaker@vumc.org.

sec.title: Context
sec.p: Pseudohypoparathyroidism (PHP) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by early-onset obesity and multihormone resistance. To treat abnormal weight gain and prevent complications such as diabetes, we must understand energy balance and glucose homeostasis in PHP types 1A and 1B.

sec.title: Objective
sec.p: The aim of this study was to evaluate food intake, energy expenditure, and glucose homeostasis in children with PHP.

sec.title: Design
sec.p: Assessments included resting energy expenditure (REE), physical activity, food intake, sucrose preference, questionnaires, endocrine status, and auxological status. All patients underwent an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT).

sec.title: Patients
sec.p: We assessed 16 children with PHP1A, three with PHP1B, and 15 healthy controls.

sec.title: Main Outcome Measures
sec.p: Food intake during an ad lib buffet meal and glucose at five time points during OGTT.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: PHP1A and control groups were well matched. Participants with PHP1A had significantly lower REE without concomitant change in food intake or physical activity. At baseline, participants with PHP1A had significantly lower fasting glucose and insulin resistance. During OGTT, participants with PHP1A had significantly delayed peak glucose and a slower rate of glucose decline despite similar oral glucose insulin sensitivity. Participants with PHP1A had 0.46% lower HbA1c levels than controls from a clinic database after adjustment for OGTT 2-hour glucose. The PHP1B group was similar to the PHP1A group.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In contrast to other monogenic obesity syndromes, our results support reduced energy expenditure, not severe hyperphagia, as the primary cause of abnormal weight gain in PHP. Patients with PHP are at high risk for dysglycemia without reduced insulin sensitivity.

abstract.p: Patients with PHP1A have reduced energy expenditure without concomitant change in food intake or physical activity, resulting in early-onset obesity. They may also have increased risk of dysglycemia.

funding-source.named-content: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases
National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences
